content:
Tommy shifted uncomfortably, feeling like he was carrying a heavy weight on his shoulders. "I know," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "But I can't tell him. I just...I can't."

"Why not?" Mark pressed. "It's your dad, Tommy. He has a right to know."

Tommy shook his head, his eyes brimming with tears. "I know, but it's not that simple. What if we mess up the timeline or something? What if telling him changes everything and we don't exist in the future anymore? And what if he doesn't believe us?"

Mark frowned. "But what about you? Don't you want to know what your dad was like when he was our age?"

Tommy hesitated, thinking back to all the stories his dad had told him about growing up. He had always been curious, but he had never expected to actually meet him in the past. "Of course I do," he said softly. "But I don't know if I'm ready for this. It's too much to handle."

Mark reached out and placed a hand on Tommy's shoulder. "We'll figure it out together," he said reassuringly. "We'll make sure everything goes smoothly."

Tommy nodded, feeling a little more hopeful. "Okay," he said. "We'll do it tomorrow. But we have to be careful. We can't mess this up."

The two boys stayed up for most of the night, talking quietly about their plan and their concerns. Tommy couldn't shake the feeling of apprehension that clung to him, but he also felt a sense of excitement and wonder. He was about to meet his dad as a teenager, and he couldn't wait to see what he was like.

The next morning, they woke up early and walked to the diner where Davey worked. Tommy's heart was pounding as they entered the diner, scanning the room for any sign of his dad.

There he was, behind the counter, looking tired but determined as he took orders and served coffee. Tommy watched him with a sense of awe, feeling like he was seeing him for the first time.

They sat down at a booth and ordered breakfast, trying to act casual as they waited for Davey to come over. When he finally did, Tommy felt his heart skip a beat.

"Hey, boys," Davey said with a smile. "What can I get for you?"

Tommy took a deep breath, feeling his nerves getting the best of him. "Um, could we talk to you for a minute?" he asked hesitantly.

Davey looked at him curiously. "Sure, what's up?"

Tommy hesitated, unsure of how to begin. "I...um, I just wanted to say that...you're a really great guy, Davey. And I...I just wanted to thank you for talking to us yesterday."

Davey smiled. "No problem, kiddo. It's always good to help out a couple of kids in need."

Tommy felt his throat tighten. He had to tell him. He had to know. "Davey," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "Do you ever feel like...like you don't fit in? Like people don't understand you?"

Davey looked at him quizzically. "Sure, I guess. But that's just part of growing up, you know? You learn to find your place in the world."

Tommy took a deep breath. "I know," he said. "But sometimes it's really hard. And sometimes it feels like...like you're all alone."

Davey's expression softened. "I understand," he said. "Believe me, I do. But you
